section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: You need a Java Virtual Machine (JVM) 1.4 or higher to run the program.
If you are in doubt of, what this means, then please read the section "Testing for and installing a Java Virtual Machine" below.

section.title: Download
section.p: The newest version of the program can be downloaded from the files section of the project website.
Alternatively you can get access to the newest untested code in the version control system.

section.title: Running and Installation
section.p: Unfortunately at the moment there is no sophisticated way to install and run DingsBums?!.
Unpack the zip-file you downloaded and place the contents into a directory, where you have read/write access.

On Mac OS X you can simply double-click the dingsbums.jar file to launch the application. All others have to get a command prompt (see below how to do that), change to the directory containing the application and then type the following: java -jar dingsbums.jar.

section.title: Samples
section.p: In the sample directory, which is included in the zip-file, you can find a version of the author's personal German-Danish vocabulary as well as a learning stack about the countries of the European Union to get you started.

section.title: Testing for and installing a Java Virtual Machine
section.p: A Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is included in a Java Runtime environment (JRE) for end users, and Java Development Kits (Java SDK or JDK) for programmers. The way to test whether you have a JVM in the right version depends on you operating system (e.g. Microsoft Windows).
"Test your Java Virtual Machine" lets you do the test in your browser. This web page is part of the official Java site at java.com, which contains lots of help around Java.

If you happen to be the owner of an Apple Macintosh you can find additional information at Apple's Java pages and Java Frequently Asked Questions. Unfortunately there is no recent JVM for Mac OS 9 and earlier.
